Award.AwardTitle: LOCUS: Levels of Conceptual Understanding in Statistics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop two tests (instruments) to assess conceptual understanding of statistics.

The instruments are based on the levels A/B and on level C of statistical understanding development as described in the American Statistical Association Guidelines for Assessment and Instruction of Statistics Education (GAISE) framework. These instruments will be used to assess knowledge of statistics by grades 6-12 students. The instruments will have multiple-choice and constructed response (CR) items. The CR items will have scoring rubrics. The assessments will be pilot tested in school districts in six states. The instruments will be used by teachers to analyze students' growth in understanding of statistics and will be useable for both formative and summative purposes. An assessment blueprint will be developed based on the GAISE framework for selecting and constructing both fixed-choice and open-ended items. An evidenced-based designed process will be used to develop the assessments. The blueprint will be used by the test development committee to develop items. These items will be reviewed by the advisory board considering the main statistics topics to be included on the assessments. Through a layering process, the assessments will be piloted, revised, and field tested with students in grades 6-12 in six states. A three-parameter IRT model will be used in analyzing the items. The work will be done by researchers at the University of Florida with the support of those at the University of Minnesota, the Educational Testing Service, and Kenyon College. Researchers from TERC will conduct a process evaluation with several feedback and redesign cycles.

The assessments will be aligned with the Common Core State Standards for mathematics (CCSSM) and made available as open-source to teachers through a website. The research team will interact with the state consortia developing assessments to measure students? attainment of the CCSSM. As such, the assessments have the potential of being used by a large proportion of students in the country. The more conceptually-based items will provide teachers with concrete examples of what statistics students in grades 6-12 should know.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-funded Levels of Conceptual Understanding in Statistics (LOCUS) Project (DRL-1118168) developed a series of valid and reliable assessments of statistical understanding. These assessments measure understanding across levels of development as identified in the Guidelines for Assessment and Instruction in Statistics Education (GAISE) Report: A Pre-K-12 Curriculum Framework. LOCUS assessments measure statistical understanding at two levels: Beginning/Intermediate and Intermediate/Advanced. The intent of these assessments is to provide teachers, educational leaders, assessment specialists, and researchers with valid and reliable assessments of conceptual understanding in statistics consistent with standards across the United States.

The LOCUS project engaged in an evidence-centered design process to develop a framework for the assessments. This framework provided a blueprint for experts in mathematics education, statistics education, statistics, and assessment to develop a complete series of assessments with implications for classroom teachers, teacher educators, and researchers. Although the project proposed to develop one valid, reliable, and equated assessment per level, the project team ultimately developed a series of ten valid, reliable, and equated assessments. The project team also developed a platform for assessments to be administered, and automatically scored, via the project website which will be maintained beyond the duration of the project at: https://locus.statisticseducation.org.

The LOCUS assessments and website have been reviewed and endorsed by the American Statistical Association and National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. Although initially designed for students in grades 6-12, the LOCUS assessments have been administered to students in undergraduate statistics, teachers, and health professionals. To date, over 50,000 LOCUS assessments have been taken, with a majority of these administrations through the LOCUS website. The LOCUS website provides teachers, teacher educators, and researchers with a platform to create an account and administer valid, reliable, and equated assessments. The purpose of the assessments varies by the goal of the user. The primary use is for teachers or teacher educators to measure the impact of instruction through LOCUS pre- and post-assessments. Additionally, LOCUS has provided a valid and reliable tool to the statistics education research community that is being utilized in rigorous studies that aim to measure a difference due to some form of intervention. LOCUS users also have the ability to assemble their own assessments through a collection of sample items. 

The sample items for LOCUS provide the context for one of the most widely utilized features of the LOCUS website. One of the key outcomes of the LOCUS project is the freely available professional development materials that have been created. The professional development portion of the website hosts 68 multiple-choice and 33 constructed-response items. Each of the items contains commentary that aims to describe the purpose of the question and common misunderstandings that may occur. All 33 commentaries for the constructed-response questions contain the following information: Overview of the Question; Standards; Ideal Response and Scoring; Sample Responses Indicating Solid Understanding; Common Misunderstandings with Student Work; Student Performance; and Identification of Resources for Addressing Common Student Misunderstandings. To view the resources that have been making a significant impact on professional development in statistics education visit https://locus.statisticseducation.org/professional-development.

The LOCUS project has also realized its goal of providing exemplary items that aim to assess statistical understanding. The resources provided through this project have been, and continue to be, used by many of the leading test development companies in the United States. The project team is honored to have been provided the support to create the materials that are now having a major impact on the assessment, instruction, and learning of statistics in the United States.
